docs.snippet: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 29 percent -- more than analysts had predicted -- on better-than-expected sales of general business programs.   Microsoft, the world's largest personal computer softwar...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 29 percent -- more than analysts had predicted -- on better-than-expected sales of general business programs. Microsoft, the world's largest personal computer software company, said net income rose to $373 million, or 60 cents a share, from $289 million, or 48 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

docs.snippet: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose more than 32 percent on strong sales of its Windows operating system and Office package of business programs.   The world's largest maker of personal computer sof...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose more than 32 percent on strong sales of its Windows operating system and Office package of business programs. The world's largest maker of personal computer software said its net income totaled $316 million, or 51 cents a share, exceeding Wall Street's estimates by about 2 cents. Sales rose nearly 27 percent, to almost $1.25 billion.

docs.snippet: The unfolding drama that is Microsoft's blockbuster offer for Yahoo already features some of the tech world's bold-faced names, such as Steven Ballmer, Ray Ozzie, Jerry Yang and Terry Semel. The deal also includes some big-name investment banks as...
docs.lead_paragraph: The unfolding drama that is Microsoft's blockbuster offer for Yahoo already features some of the tech world's bold-faced names, such as Steven Ballmer, Ray Ozzie, Jerry Yang and Terry Semel. The deal also includes some big-name investment banks as advisers -- but not necessarily on the sides you might expect.

headline.main: MSFT-YHOO: A Look at the Advisers

docs.snippet: With competition for engineering talent in Silicon Valley as fierce as it has been since the late 1990s, if not fiercer, one crucial question about Microsoft's $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo is whether a combined company could more easily attract sof...
docs.lead_paragraph: With competition for engineering talent in Silicon Valley as fierce as it has been since the late 1990s, if not fiercer, one crucial question about Microsoft's $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo is whether a combined company could more easily attract software engineers - an increasingly precious commodity. Both companies are already fighting the perception that their most innovative days are behind them.

headline.main: Another Difficulty for a MSFT-YHOO Marriage: Recruiting

docs.snippet: What if Microsoft dropped its bid for Yahoo and bought AOL and MySpace instead? One analyst says that may be a better deal than a target that doesn't want to merge....
docs.lead_paragraph: The flirtations and betrayals among Internet giants would steam up even the hottest afternoon soap opera. In the latest round, the News Corporation, which had been playing footsie with Yahoo, has jumped into the arms of Microsoft in an effort to break up the pending union of Yahoo and Time Warner's estranged wife, AOL. Oh yes, Google, which everyone envies, is prodding all this on to keep its rivals in a state of confusion.
docs.abstract: What if Microsoft dropped its bid for Yahoo and bought AOL and MySpace instead? One analyst says that may be a better deal than a target that doesn't want to merge.

headline.main: Is Yahoo the Odd Man Out?

docs.snippet: Microsoft booked an $8.4 billion charge in the fourth quarter, swallowing a bitter pill by writing off the Nokia phone business it bought just over a year ago. It narrowly beat analysts' depressed expectations for a quarter that also saw a steep d...
docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft booked an $8.4 billion charge in the fourth quarter, swallowing a bitter pill by writing off the Nokia phone business it bought just over a year ago. It narrowly beat analysts' depressed expectations for a quarter that also saw a steep decline in personal computer sales even as it prepares to launch its latest operating system, Windows 10.
